Hi Matt, fitness sharing is meant to penalize a species the larger 
it gets.  Of course, species only tend to get very large if they 
have high fitness, which is what fitness sharing keeps in check.  If 
a species gets too large, it won't be able to keep expanding, 
thereby allowing other species a chance to explout their own niches.

But you are right that the correct fitness value to use for 
identifying the champion is the *raw* fitness.  Once fitness is 
adjusted, it's just an internal number used by NEAT to assign 
offspring.  It is no longer useful for knowing who was the objective 
best.  So use unadjusted (raw) fitness for determining the champion.

It should be noted that there are equivalent formulas for fitness 
sharing that involve a slightly different process than I used in my 
version of NEAT (and other version of NEAT may be based on how I did 
it).  These alternative forumulations actually do exactly the same 
thing, but they just involve a different set of steps.  You can 
refer to the question, "Is there another way to do fitness sharing?" 
in the NEAT FAQs on the NEAT Users Page at:

http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html

This question answers a slightly different question, but it notes 
that the following formula is equivalent to adjusting fitnesses and 
doing what I did in my NEAT code, even though there is no adjustment 
step:

Offspring = (AverageSpeciesFitness / 
Total_of_AverageSpeciesFitnesss) * PopulationSize 


By the way, do you plan to open your version of NEAT to the public?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Matt Simmerson" <m.simmerson@b...> 
wrote:
> Hi
> 
> Just a quick intro to myself.  I have been 'playing' around with 
NN's
> and GA for a few years now and came accross NEAT through Mat
> Buckland's excellent book.  I have implemented my own version (as
> that's what I am good at) in Java.  Been reading the posts for the
> last few days and there is obviously a wealth of talent and
> information out there, hopefully I can use it.
> 
> I am using NEAT to predict FTSE 100 movement and weather 
forecasting.
>  I have tested my implementation with XOR and it works just fine. 
> Obviously, the domain(s) that interest me are somewhat more 
complex.
> 
> My biggest confusion is about speciation.  I understand the
> compatability metric, but what I haven't grasped is the role of
> fitness sharing and its effect on a specie/population.  Ken's paper
> says that the fitness is reduced by the size of the specie.  Is 
that
> meant to be a penalty to more populous species?  My fitness 
function
> currently tends towards zero for more fit memebers.
> 
> As I save (to disc) the best from each genration it is important 
that
> I save the correct best member.  i.e. the one with the best raw
> fitness or the one with the best shared fitness.
> 
> Sorry if this is rambling, but I want to clear this in my own mind.
> 
> Thanks for listening.
> 
> Matt
